Wo to the multitude... —The word ‘woe’ (הוי hôy) may be either an interjection simply directing the attention to them, or it may be a word indicating approaching calamity and judgment (see the note atIsaiah 5:6). Gesenius supposes that it is rather the language of compassion, on account of the evil which they threatened to bring upon the people of God, like1 Kings 13:30 , ‘Ah! wo, my brother!’

The multitude of many people —Or, the tumult of many nations—a description of the noise attending an invading army made up of many nations mingled together, such as was that of Sennacherib.

Which make a noise... —This is a beautiful description of a vast army, and of the shouting, the tumult, the din, which attends its march. The same comparison occurs inJeremiah 6:23; Psalm 65:7 (seeEzekiel 43:2; Revelation 1:15; Revelation 14:2; Revelation 19:6).

And to the rushing of nations —The rushing of mighty armies to conquest.
